Class calc3Dtree

java.lang.Object
  nescent.phyloGeoRef.calc3Dtree

public class calc3Dtree
extends java.lang.Object

This class handles the calculations of the trees.

Constructor Summary
calc3Dtree()
           
 
Method Summary
 void assignBinaryNodes(Phylogeny my_phy, java.util.ArrayList coordList)
          Algorithm: Each external node, "leaf" is assigned a lat/long from the coordlist all subsequent nodes are then placed in the middle of the child nodes at altitude alt.
 void assignMaridianCoords(Phylogeny my_phy, java.util.ArrayList coordList)
          This function has a feature that checks if any nodes have children that cross the 180 meridian.
 void assignMultipleObservations(Phylogeny my_phy, java.util.ArrayList coordList)
          This doesn't quite work yet -- don't use it unless you fix it The best way I can think to do this is create a polygon in KML that is bound by the points and put the leaf of the tree in the center of the polygon.
 void assignNodeCoords(Phylogeny my_phy, java.util.ArrayList coordList)
          This function assigned coordinates to the nodes of the tree.
 void lazyAssignNodeCoords(Phylogeny my_phy, java.util.ArrayList coordList)
          This just calls assignBinaryNodes -- it was mostly used for testing and can probably be removed

Method Detail

assignBinaryNodes

public void assignBinaryNodes(Phylogeny my_phy,
                              java.util.ArrayList coordList)
Algorithm: Each external node, "leaf" is assigned a lat/long from the coordlist all subsequent nodes are then placed in the middle of the child nodes at altitude alt. TODO: still need to add xmeridian check This is probably not a necessary function, I think the regular assignNodeCoords will do the same thing as this function.

Parameters:
my_phy -
coordList -

This just calls assignBinaryNodes -- it was mostly used for testing and can probably be removed

assignMultipleObservations

public void assignMultipleObservations(Phylogeny my_phy,
                                       java.util.ArrayList coordList)
This doesn't quite work yet -- don't use it unless you fix it The best way I can think to do this is create a polygon in KML that is bound by the points and put the leaf of the tree in the center of the polygon.

Parameters:
my_phy -
coordList -

assignMaridianCoords

public void assignMaridianCoords(Phylogeny my_phy,
                                 java.util.ArrayList coordList)
This function has a feature that checks if any nodes have children that cross the 180 meridian. If so, it will do a special calculation to determine the midpoint.

Parameters:
my_phy -
coordList -
